results.headline: 3 Tales on Disappearance of Gay Porn Star
results.summary_short: Despite marvelously moody visuals and a tantalizing setup, “Pornography: A Thriller” finally puzzles more than it pleases.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pornography

results.headline: A Baseball Story
results.summary_short: “The Perfect Game” tells the tale of a ragtag Mexican team that improbably wins the Little League World Series.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Perfect Game

results.headline: It’s a Bird, It’s a Plane, It’s a Blood Bath
results.summary_short: A story about a teenager who yearns to be a superhero, “Kick-Ass” is fast, periodically spit-funny and often grotesquely violent.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kick-Ass

results.headline: Buy, Buy, Buy, to Keep Up With the You-Know-Whos
results.summary_short: In “The Joneses,” a fake family is dispatched to suburbia to seduce the natives into buying more stuff.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Joneses

results.headline: A Sexual Advance, a Savage Beating, Years of Guilt
results.summary_short: In “Handsome Harry” a Vietnam veteran, played by Jamey Sheridan, takes a journey into an unpleasant past.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Handsome Harry

results.headline: Remaking an Ancient Farce From 2007
results.summary_short: Neil LaBute’s version of “Death at a Funeral” moves the action to Los Angeles with a predominantly black cast.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Death at a Funeral

results.headline: Genteel Lives Unsettled in Uruguay
results.summary_short: Anthony Hopkins and Laura Linney star in a Merchant Ivory production without Ismail Merchant.
results.display_title: The City of Your Final Destination

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The City of Your Final Destination

results.headline: Children Left Behind
results.summary_short: A documentary about the American public-school system in New Jersey focuses on corrupt administrators, teachers’ unions and school boards.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Cartel

results.headline: Fassbinder’s Vibrating Sci-Fi Questions About Reality
results.summary_short: Rainer Werner Fassbinder’s “World on a Wire,” which will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art in a restored 35-millimeter print, will certainly be familiar to fans of “The Matrix.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of World on a Wire

results.headline: A Fight Against Bigotry and Violence, Lasting 45 Years and 8 ½ Hours
results.summary_short: Connie Field’s seven-part documentary chronicles the fight against apartheid.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Have You Heard from Johannesburg?

results.headline: Dear God: A Young Boy Needs a Cure. Please Help.
results.summary_short: In this Christian-themed film, a child with brain cancer writes letters to God and thereby touches the heart of an embittered, hard-drinking postal carrier.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Letters to God

results.headline: Sin and Comeuppance Down Under
results.summary_short: “The Square” by Nash Edgerton, an Australian stuntman turned filmmaker, turns a humdrum backwater into a black hole of crime and punishment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Square

results.headline: Deaf, and Trying to Make It in Showbiz
results.summary_short: This documentary about deaf entertainers focuses on four performers with varying degrees of hearing impairment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of See what I'm saying

results.headline: Perfectly Happy, Until They Venture Into the Outside World
results.summary_short: “Everyone Else” dissects the relationship between two young lovers, touching on many of the issues and anxieties that color all relationships.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Everyone Else

results.headline: Fictional History: What It Was Like to Start Rock ’n’ Roll, Sort Of
results.summary_short: Jerry Zaks’s film offers a fictionalized biography of Leonard Chess, the rock ’n’ roll record pioneer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Who Do You Love

results.headline: That Fire, Lighted and Doused
results.summary_short: Tom DiCillo’s film “When You’re Strange” assembles clips of the Doors shot between 1966 and 1971, with solemn narration by Johnny Depp.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When You're Strange

results.headline: A Family Lives to Drink, and, Yes, Drinks to Live
results.summary_short: A Belgian film about the experiences of an alcoholic clan, as observed by a 13-year-old boy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Misfortunates

results.headline: Father-Son Conflict on Streets of San Francisco
results.summary_short: Benjamin Bratt stars in this movie, set in the Mission District of San Francisco in the pre-gentrifiation 1970s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La Mission

results.headline: Twins Who Are as Eccentric as the Movies They Made
results.summary_short: George and Mike Kuchar, twin brothers from the Bronx, are prolific and inventive American filmmakers of the past half-century, and among the most eccentric.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It Came From Kuchar

results.headline: What’s the Matter With Corn Syrup?
results.summary_short: An indictment of industrial farming, this documentary provides practical solutions for healthier agriculture and eating.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fresh
